questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configures port security on a Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switch. The requirement is to prevent any newly learned MAC addresses from forwarding traffic on the interface. Also, the already learned MAC addresses must not be affected by the changes. Which configuration meets these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
For now I think B is right because NTFY = F, but I'm not 100% sure if is the correct solution

Selected Answer: B
Protect because NTFY is F

Selected Answer: B
protect ad NTFY is set to false in the exibit

I will vote for A - restrict, from Cisco 9000 guide:

Protect mode is not supported on 7.0(3)I5(2) release

Selected Answer: A
restrict should be the one

comments.content: I had in mind >>A<< with Restrict

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I will vote for B as normally admins should be informed about that incident

Selected Answer: A
Protect—This mode permits traffic from known MAC addresses to continue to be forwarded while dropping traffic from unknown MAC addresses when over the allowed MAC address limit. When configured with this mode, no notification action is taken when traffic is dropped.
Restrict—This mode permits traffic from known MAC addresses to continue to be forwarded while dropping traffic from unknown MAC addresses when over the allowed MAC address limit. When configured with this mode, a syslog message is logged, a Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) trap is sent, and a violation counter is incremented when traffic is dropped.
I think A or B, both could be correct.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
Example: Configuring Port Security on an Orphan Port
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/7-x/security/configuration/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Security_Configuration_Guide_7x/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Security_Configuration_Guide_7x_chapter_010101.html

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the streaming telemetry component on the left to its function on the right. Not all components are used.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct
vzAny: This rapid referral facilitates management by enabling the configuration of a single contract point for all terminal groups within a VRF. It also optimizes hardware resource consumption by applying the contract to this single group rather than to each group of terminals individually.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct: 
''There are two typical use cases for vzAny:

Free communication between EPGs within the same VRF, as described in Free Intra-VRF Communication.

Many-to-one communication allowing all EPGs within the same VRF to consume a shared service from a single EPG, as described in more detail in Many-to-One Communication.''
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/mso/3x/configuration/cisco-aci-multi-site-configuration-guide-301/aci-multi-site-use-case-vzany.html

Why not D? Implementing the vzAny feature allows EPGs to communicate with any other EPG in the fabric without specifying a specific contract. While it provides flexibility, it does not ensure that all EPGs consume the same services or reduce TCAM resources.

Selected Answer: C
vzAny would be the easiest way of doing that and I think it is consuming the least TCAM resources

Selected Answer: C
Is C:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/mso/3x/configuration/cisco-aci-multi-site-configuration-guide-301/aci-multi-site-use-case-vzany.html

choices.D: Configure a single contract provided and consumed in all EPGs.
choices.A: Configure preferred groups in the VRF for all EPGs.

questions.question_text: An engineer is implementing the Cisco ACI fabric and wants to reduce the amount of TCAM resources consumed by the fabric. The engineer also needs to ensure that all EPGs in a VRF consume the same services. Which action should be taken to meet these requirements?
Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switches are configured with LACP protocol and default aging timers. What is the impact on the LACP peer during an ISSU upgrade?

choices.D: The LACP peer session remains up.
choices.A: The LACP peer renegotiates the adjacency.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the one

Selected Answer: D
D is correct because we must configure the source IP address so monitor erspan origin ip-address 209.165.200.225 is the correct command

Selected Answer: D
Configuration Example for an IP Address as the Source for an ERSPAN Session
This example shows how to configure an IP address as the source for an ERSPAN session:

switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# monitor erspan origin ip-address 192.0.2.1
switch(config)# exit
switch(config)# copy running-config startup config

Other comments mention needing the global command at end, but on this document (right above the snippet i shared) it shows the global command at end of syntax for "ERSPAN Type III Source Session"

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5500/sw/system_management/6x/b_5500_System_Mgmt_Config_6x/b_5500_System_Mgmt_Config_602N12_chapter_010001.html#concept_5FB9BFDA3C874133805ACEEB49103891

Lol, just saw ed27 comment. Yeah. :) D.

Selected Answer: D
Can be configured without the "global". This example shows how to configure an IP address as the source for an ERSPAN session:
switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# monitor erspan origin ip-address 192.0.2.1
switch(config)# exit

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5500/sw/system_management/6x/b_5500_System_Mgmt_Config_6x/b_5500_System_Mgmt_Config_602N12_chapter_010001.pdf

Selected Answer: B
It should be B

monitor session span-session-number type erspan-source

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9500/software/release/16-10/configuration_guide/nmgmt/b_1610_nmgmt_9500_cg/configuring_erspan.html#:~:text=Step%C2%A04-,monitor%20session%20span%2Dsession%2Dnumber%20type%20erspan%2Dsource,-Example%3A

comments.content:
Correction, we need to configure IP hence the closes one is D (lack of Global flag)

monitor erspan origin ip-address ip-address global
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/5_x/nx-os/system_management/configuration/guide/sm_nx_os_cg/sm_erspan.html#:~:text=Step%202-,monitor%20erspan%20origin%20ip%2Daddress%20ip%2Daddress%20global,-Example%3A

discussion.content: It may be D, but for this command to be valid, it must be in a form "monitor erspan origin ip-address 209.165.200.225 global". It is invalid without the "global" keyword.
